description:
Sciaenops ocellatus, commonly known as the red drum or redfish, is a species of saltwater fish belonging to the family Sciaenidae. It is found along the Atlantic and Gulf coasts of the United States, from Massachusetts to Mexico.

The red drum is a relatively large fish, with a maximum recorded length of 1.2 meters (4 feet) and a maximum weight of 57 kilograms (125 pounds). It has a robust, oval-shaped body with a large, terminal mouth and a rounded, blunt head. The body is typically reddish-bronze in color, with a distinctive black spot near the base of the tail.

Red drum are opportunistic predators, feeding primarily on small fish, crustaceans, and mollusks. They are an important commercial and recreational species, valued for their firm, white flesh and sport fishing capabilities.

Biologically, Sciaenops ocellatus is a member of the drum family, known for their ability to produce drumming sounds by vibrating their swim bladders. They are found in coastal waters, estuaries, and inshore habitats, where they play a crucial role in the marine ecosystem as both predators and prey.
